etymologies: mid 17th century (originally used by sawyers as a rhythmical refrain): reduplication of the verb saw (symbolic of the sawing motion)

definitions: a long plank balanced in the middle on a fixed support, on each end of which children sit and swing up and down by pushing the ground alternately with their feet.
shortDefinitions: long plank balanced in middle on fixed support, on each end

definitions: a situation characterized by rapid, repeated changes from one state or condition to another

examples.text: the emotional seesaw of a first love affair

shortDefinitions: situation characterized by rapid, repeated changes from one state or condition to another

definitions: change rapidly and repeatedly from one position, situation, or condition to another and back again

examples.text: the market seesawed as rumors spread of an imminent cabinet reshuffle

shortDefinitions: change rapidly and repeatedly from one position

definitions: cause (something) to move back and forth or up and down rapidly and repeatedly

examples.text: Sybil seesawed the car back and forth

shortDefinitions: cause something to move back and forth or up and down rapidly
